segments.text: Joseph was startled to hear about her encounters with the rusty man, and for a while he stayed home every day of the week, mostly in the evenings.
However, as the days passed and the incident was slowly forgotten, she found herself alone again and again, an occasional day here and there, managing her pink house by herself.
These were hot and quiet summer days, but around them blew winds of war.
Thousands of reserve soldiers were called to gathering points in the south, nervously waiting for the possibility of war breaking out.
Their days there were long and exhausting, and from time to time, artists and singers came to entertain them during the unbearable wait.
One afternoon, while watering Lucy's garden, Paulette, the singer, appeared before her.
Bonjour mon amour, she said.
We have a mission.
We're performing for the soldiers tonight.
We, Leora wondered, why are we?
What can I do?
You'll play and accompany me with my songs.
You know them all by heart, and I'll sing.
And where exactly will we find a piano in the middle of nowhere in the Negev?
That's already arranged.
Robert, the caretaker from the French holiday village who brings you the horse in the winter, will load the village's piano onto the horse trailer and come with us.
He'll also bring speakers and amplifiers.
You'll see, it'll be great.
It amused her a bit, such a strange improvisation.
But she didn't have anything better to do anyway.
Two hours later, she squeezed in with Politt into the car with the horse trailer carrying the piano.
And within an hour, they reached the assembly area.
A friendly officer welcomed them happily, enlisted a few soldiers to lower the piano onto a slightly elevated area.
where Paulette would also stand and sing.
Soldiers started arriving en masse from every direction and settled around, not all young, looking a bit tired and sweaty, glad for the distraction.
Hundreds of soldiers.
She sat on the chair placed before the piano, not quite understanding what she was doing there.
All her life she played only for herself and suddenly so many people.
Only Paulette, this petite girl with her bell-like voice, who had already performed on so many stages and clubs in Israel and around the world, instilled confidence in her.
She handed her a list of songs and said, Maybe we'll change the order, but I'll tell you in advance.
They spoke to each other in English.
Pullit was actually Moroccan, Moroccan nobility, a petite girl with huge black eyes and eyelashes like fans over them.
She and her family had immigrated to the country five years earlier and settled in a villa not far from the pink house.
Because of their shared love for music, a warm connection was immediately formed between Pullit and Lucy and Joseph.
This is how Leora learned all the wonderful songs Pullit picked like tweezers as her repertoire.
Now, Paulette climbed onto a stage the soldiers had improvised from 20 crates, took the microphone in her hands, and tested it, making some background sounds.
From the far end, where the soldiers sat, they called Leora's name.
She turned her head and saw someone making their way to her among the soldiers who made space for him.
She couldn't believe her eyes.
It was her best friend's father from her studies in Tel Aviv.
They hugged joyfully, and he was overwhelmed with pride.
Well done, girl.
I'll find a phone right away to tell at home.
Two minutes later, Polet's voice was carried across the Negev.
Lyora accompanied her, playing the keys almost automatically, knowing that Polet was right.
She just knew her songs by heart.
The soldiers were thrilled.
These were the most beautiful foreign songs, in French, Spanish and English.
Of course, they knew most of them, sang along and clapped hands.
After about an hour, she concluded with an amazing song, one that only people with a big voice like hers could master, opening on her own acapella.
To dream the impossible dream, to fight for the right without question or pause, to be willing to march into hell for a heavenly cause, how relevant the lyrics of this song were.
With the song's eng, there was a moment of silence.
and then suddenly the soldiers stood up and clapped excitedly, unwilling to part.
Pullet thanked them again and again, forcing Leora to stand and join her.
Thank this girl who agreed to come with me and play.
She stood before them, embarrassed in jeans, a t-shirt and a braid down her back.
Forgetting she was barefoot, her sandals left by the piano, smiling with a mix of embarrassment and great happiness.
catching the feeling that she helped cheer up the soldiers, most of whom were fathers, hoping in her heart that there would be no war.
In hindsight and without knowing it, this was the concert heralding the war, because the next morning the six-day war broke out.
A few days earlier, they had filled sandbags around a not-so-large trench they dug by the exit from the kitchen, which was supposed to provide them shelter in case of bombing and alarms.

but somehow the alarms always sounded early in the morning, and Joseph, with a kind of infectious indifference, would say, they won't let a person drink coffee in peace, and simply continued to sit with her beside him, sipping coffee leisurely as if there was no war outside.

It lasted only six days, came, passed, and seemingly vanished, but left pain in the form of familiar names of the dead and wounded, and the trench with the sandbags remained to mar the kitchen entrance for many months after.
so they wouldn't forget that there had been a war long after it was over.
